text: hi my name is Rebecca and in today's

in okay so I've written some notes on

in affirmative sentences affirmative
sentences means positive sentences the
opposite of negative we're going to look
at some examples in a minute so hang on
any is used in negative sentences and
also in questions alright so let's take
an example so you understand these
points I have some money now here we
used some because it was an informative
sentence it's a positive sentence I have
some money I cannot say I have any money
I have some now let's look at the next
example which is negative I don't have
any money I don't have anyone now we
used an e because any is used in a
negative sentence all right next one do
you have any money

that's generally how it works
another example do you have any salt you

languages in all these cases we are
using any because it is in fact a
question
so that's the basic rule that will tell
you whether to use some or whether to

points okay sometimes some is used in a

answer all right when we expect a

is the basic rule this is an exception
let's look at the example of the
exception would you like some soup so
when you ask somebody would you like
some soup we're hoping that they will
say yes because we want to serve them
right so we don't say would you like any
soup we would say we would you like some
soup that's more common or could I have
some cake if you ask someone could I
have some cake you're hoping that
they're going to say yes and that's why
that you're using the word son all right
and the last point another exception is
we use the word any when we have the
words never or hardly or without in the
sentence so we could say for example he
never has any time not he never has some
time but he never has any time or we
could say he hardly has any salt he
hardly has any time he hardly has any
books okay
or he passed the exam without making any

this is the basic rule when we come back
